video.title: Trek to Yomi & Ravenous Devils (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text: *INTRO MUSIC*

I should probably learn Japanese. Seems
to come up a lot in my job, especially in

droughty seasons when the disgusting 
triple-A pie-eating contest has to take

a break to clean up all the puke and I
have a chance to try all the little

manageable Mr. Kiplings the Japanese
industry churns out. Thanks to that, I

officially know more about the procedures
and traditions of Japanese high school

life than I do about those of the actual
high school I dropped out of. But what

a refreshing break it is to now cover a
game that&#39;s merely set in Japan. And

inspired by Japanese movies. And voiced
by Japanese actors. But! Importantly! Not

developed in Japan, but in Poland. Poland
and Japan have a lot in common, I think.

They&#39;re joint presidents of the &quot;not
particularly nostalgic for the 1940s&quot;

club. Anyway, Trek To Yomi, which
translates loosely as Highway to Hell,

is inspired by Akira Kurosawa films, just
like Ghost of Tsushima, but is determined

to out-Kurosawa Ghost of Tsushima at
every turn. It&#39;s all in slightly

overexposed black and white, it&#39;s got a
room by room fixed camera setup where

every moment could be a frame from a
Kurosawa film, and combat&#39;s modelled on

that Samurai movie thing where two dudes
make like three lightning fast sword

movements and then one of them keels
over gushing red water like a leaky
dishwasher in an Italian restaurant.

The plot is pretty standard fare: you&#39;re
a lone Samurai with a face like a brick

wall on a windy hillside, your duty is to
protect your village from bandits and

inevitably bandits show up. But it&#39;s hard
to hold it against them because there

are very few who have the sheer
infectious lust for life as the evil

bandits in a samurai movie. Just listen
to them guffawing as you hose down the

scenery with the arterial spray of all
their friends. They&#39;re so determined not

to let you ruin their lovely day. Trek to
Yomi&#39;s plot suffers from a bad case of

&quot;So THIS is what we&#39;re doing now?&quot; Where
there&#39;s about nine different inciting

incidents and it takes way too bloody
long to get through all of them. In which

case I need to drop a spoiler warning
&#39;cos in explaining the setup of the plot

I&#39;ll give away like two thirds of it. At
first we&#39;re a novice samurai whose master

gets killed by the big baddie, which is
such a trite scenario I&#39;m pretty sure

they sell prewritten sympathy cards for
it. But then we forget about that and go

off to save a village from bandits,
promptly fuck that up, try to save our

own village from bandits,
fuck that up too,

Die and wake up in Japanese hell, where
we must journey to confront our sins and

those we wronged in life. Okay, THIS is
what we&#39;re doing, gotcha. Took your

fucking time getting to the point.
Considering the sameyness of the

environments up to now. The different
nuances between nineteen monochrome

bandit-besieged Japanese farming villages
being kinda lost on me. As for gameplay,

it&#39;s a strictly linear path that would
almost make it akin to a Limbo style,

&quot;keep moving to the right&quot; narrative
indie game if it didn&#39;t keep branching

off into partially hidden side paths
where there will inevitably be one

collectible and some shuriken ammo even
though I barely used those useless

fucking Christmas ornaments. Combat
consists of sword duelling along a 2D

plane in a sort of original Prince of
Persia style, where the game trains you

in a range of light attack-heavy attack
combos, parries, up-strikes, down-strikes,

back-strikes, round-the-garden-path-strikes,
and for a while you wonder why it

bothers when virtually every enemy you fight
drops almost instantly if you just run

up to them wobbling your sword back
and forth like a windscreen wiper.

But things click better once you do
descend to Yomi and start hacking your

way through zombies and spirits that
actually pose a challenge and the odd

huge gribbly boss monster that shows up
to complain about the noise. Even then,

though, the combat lacks a certain punch.
There&#39;s something off about the parrying

animation. Every time I do it, it feels
more like the other dude deliberately

stopped his swing to give me a chance
to react. Trek to Yomi, I am a

professional Youtuber, I get condescended
to quite enough in daily life. On the

whole I&#39;d describe Trek to Yomi as &quot;slow
to start, but worth finishing.&quot; It&#39;s

short by design so even if it doesn&#39;t
click for you after a while, you might

as well finish it &#39;cos there&#39;ll only be
like two hours left and then you&#39;ll be

able to get into some very stimulating
online arguments. But it does leave us

with some time to fill, so let&#39;s talk
about another short game I played this

week, Ravenous Devils. Which is... okay.
You know those light shop-stroke-restaurant

management games usually based around
activating timers at different workstations

and trying to meet customers&#39; needs
before they get annoyed and walk out?

Exactly, that thing that there&#39;s ten
billion of on browser and mobile because

it&#39;s one of those genres that are weirdly
popular with housebound mums who can&#39;t

afford to pass the time hiring pool
cleaners to fuck? Well this is that, but

with Sweeney Todd. Sort of. So as well
as preparing recipes in the kitchen and

delivering them to waiting customers you
also have to make time for murdering the

absolute bollocks off of Victorian
gentlefolk, stripping the bodies and

dunking them in the meat grinder. I was
about to drop it like freshly oven

roasted bellend when I saw what kind of
game it was, but I was actually rather

impressed by the theming. When you think
about it murder is a good match for

casual restaurant sims because as a genre
they&#39;ve probably contributed to a small

but not insignificant percentage of
childhood deaths by neglect. And I

appreciated the rather effective little
touches that went into the art and

animation. The leg sticking out of the
meat grinder, the way the murderous wife

walks around the kitchen like she&#39;s just
got so much on today but she&#39;s determined

not to let it take the
spring out of her step.

Ravenous Devils is a rather insubstantial
snack of a game but I could go for

seconds. I rather liked what story there
was. I mentioned when I was talking about

Haven a while back, we don&#39;t see enough
games that centre around a loving couple

with equal billing, and honestly it was
just nice to see. Mr. and Mrs. Muttonchop

Murder are completely devoted to each
other and completely round the houses bat

shit banana sandwich kill crazy on all
fours and I&#39;m fucking well here for it.

But at the end of the day, it is just a
timer-based light restaurant management

sim like so many others and a fairly
flimsy one at that - ten or so missions

and that&#39;s about it. Buying all the
different ingredients to cook with didn&#39;t

seem to do anything except add needless
complications, and the upgrade path

stopped dead at four restaurant tables
and three ovens. Where&#39;s the ambition,

guys? I want to keep expanding. Get the
wealthy connoisseurs of old Landon tahhhn

to flock to this up-and-coming new bistro
in the rapidly gentrifying area with the

mysteriously decreasing population
density. Fuck it, why not ring in the new

century by opening an entire chain of
inexpensive burger outlets? Did you find

a wedding ring in your quarter pounder?
Lucky you! You found the Happy Meal toy.
Thank you for visiting McDonner Party.
*OUTRO MUSIC*
This video was made possible by...
Closed Captions by @willcblogs
